elements.content: The prototype three-dimensional metal−organic framework Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O (MOF-1) and two-dimensional Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2·(DMF) (MOF-2) can be reversibly transformed with each other in which the activated MOF-2 exhibits high selective gas adsorption with respect to C2H2/CO2 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: The prototype three-dimensional metal-organic framework Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)⋅4DMF⋅0.5H2O (MOF-1) and two-dimensional Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2⋅(DMF) (MOF-2) can be reversibly transformed with each other in which the activated MOF-2 exhibits high selective gas adsorption with respect to C2H2/CO2 at room temperature.

elements.content: The prototype three-dimensional metal−organic framework Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O (MOF-1) and two-dimensional Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2·(DMF) (MOF-2) can be reversibly transformed with each other in which the activated MOF-2 exhibits high selective gas adsorption with respect to C2H2/CO2 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: The prototype three-dimensional metal-organic framework Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)⋅4DMF⋅0.5H2O (MOF-1) and two-dimensional Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2⋅(DMF) (MOF-2) can be reversibly transformed with each other in which the activated MOF-2 exhibits high selective gas adsorption with respect to C2H2/CO2 at room temperature.

elements.content: The last two decades have witnessed the rapid progress of the porous metal−organic framework (MOF) materials. This new type of porous material is quite unique in terms of their extraordinarily high porosity for gas storage, tunable and functional pore size and site for separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and sensing. Such special features are attributed to the richness of metal ions and organic linkers of diverse geometry and length; thus, a variable of porous MOFs of different structures and porosities can be readily constructed. The chemical bond to connect metal ions and organic linkers within porous MOFs is mainly a coordination bond which is weaker than a covalent bond, so some self-assembled porous MOFs exhibit a flexible, robust structural feature and show unique structural transformation, selective recognition and separation, and hysteretic adsorption behaviors. Furthermore, the weak bond between the metal ions and organic linkers also make porous MOFs less stable than porous traditional zeolite materials, and thus suitable handling, activation, and preservation are certainly necessary and important to keep porous MOFs active for their daily usage, particularly for those promising porous MOFs which might be commercialized in the near future. The effect of moisture (mainly water molecules) on the destabilization of some porous MOFs has been well noticed, but the reason for the framework destabilization has still not been clearly understood, and very few examples of structural transformation responsible for such framework destabilization have been realized experimentally by single X-ray and powder diffraction studies. During our studies on a prototype three-dimensional (3D) MOF Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O (MOF-1) for separation of small gas molecules and alkane isomers, we noticed that Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O in the air can be transformed into a related two-dimensional (2D) MOF Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2·(DMF) (MOF-2, one of the first MOFs exhibiting permanent porosity). At the meantime, MOF-2 can also be transformed back to MOF-1 after the organic pillar linker Dabco was added to MOF-2 in DMF at 110 °C for 2 days. Herein we report the detailed single and powder X-ray diffraction studies on this reversible 2D-3D framework transformation, and selective gas adsorption behavior of these two porous MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The last two decades have witnessed the rapid progress of the porous metal-organic framework (MOF) materials. This new type of porous material is quite unique in terms of their extraordinarily high porosity for gas storage, tunable and functional pore size and site for separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and sensing. Such special features are attributed to the richness of metal ions and organic linkers of diverse geometry and length; thus, a variable of porous MOFs of different structures and porosities can be readily constructed. The chemical bond to connect metal ions and organic linkers within porous MOFs is mainly a coordination bond which is weaker than a covalent bond, so some self-assembled porous MOFs exhibit a flexible, robust structural feature and show unique structural transformation, selective recognition and separation, and hysteretic adsorption behaviors. Furthermore, the weak bond between the metal ions and organic linkers also make porous MOFs less stable than porous traditional zeolite materials, and thus suitable handling, activation, and preservation are certainly necessary and important to keep porous MOFs active for their daily usage, particularly for those promising porous MOFs which might be commercialized in the near future. The effect of moisture (mainly water molecules) on the destabilization of some porous MOFs has been well noticed, but the reason for the framework destabilization has still not been clearly understood, and very few examples of structural transformation responsible for such framework destabilization have been realized experimentally by single X-ray and powder diffraction studies. During our studies on a prototype three-dimensional (3D) MOF Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)⋅4DMF⋅0.5H2O (MOF-1) for separation of small gas molecules and alkane isomers, we noticed that Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)⋅4DMF⋅0.5H2O in the air can be transformed into a related two-dimensional (2D) MOF Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2⋅(DMF) (MOF-2, one of the first MOFs exhibiting permanent porosity). At the meantime, MOF-2 can also be transformed back to MOF-1 after the organic pillar linker Dabco was added to MOF-2 in DMF at 110 °C for 2 days. Herein we report the detailed single and powder X-ray diffraction studies on this reversible 2D-3D framework transformation, and selective gas adsorption behavior of these two porous MOFs.

elements.content: Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O (MOF-1) was synthesized according to the published procedure. Prism-shaped colorless crystals of MOF-2 were obtained after exposing MOF 1 in the air for more than 36 h, washed with DMF, and dried in the air. Their identities were confirmed by both X-ray single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies. These two MOF samples were used for gas adsorption studies. The regenerated MOF 1 was obtained as crystalline product by the following reaction: A mixture of MOF-2 (0.2781 g, 0.87 mmol) and DABCO (0.056 g, 0.50 mmol) was suspended in DMF (5 mL) and heated in a vial (20 mL) at 110 °C for 48 h.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)⋅4DMF⋅0.5H2O (MOF-1) was synthesized according to the published procedure. Prism-shaped colorless crystals of MOF-2 were obtained after exposing MOF 1 in the air for more than 36 h, washed with DMF, and dried in the air. Their identities were confirmed by both X-ray single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies. These two MOF samples were used for gas adsorption studies. The regenerated MOF 1 was obtained as crystalline product by the following reaction: A mixture of MOF-2 (0.2781 g, 0.87 mmol) and DABCO (0.056 g, 0.50 mmol) was suspended in DMF (5 mL) and heated in a vial (20 mL) at 110 °C for 48 h.

elements.content: The full hemisphere data were collected on a SMART APEX diffractometer with Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). After the data integration (SAINT) and semiempirical absorption correction based on equivalent reflections (SADABS), the structure was solved by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier techniques (SHEXLTL). The detailed crystallographic data for desolvated MOF-1 and as-synthesized MOF-2 are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray Crystallography

The full hemisphere data were collected on a SMART APEX diffractometer with Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). After the data integration (SAINT) and semiempirical absorption correction based on equivalent reflections (SADABS), the structure was solved by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier techniques (SHEXLTL). The detailed crystallographic data for desolvated MOF-1 and as-synthesized MOF-2 are listed in Table .

The X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance system equipped with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) at a scan rate of 10 s deg−1. The gas sorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 volumetric gas adsorption instrument. Typically, a sample of MOF-1 Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O (150−200 mg) was loaded and, prior to the measurements, evacuated by heating to 150 °C for 16 h until the outgas rate was <5 μm Hg/min. For MOF-2, the evacuation was carried out at 140 °C under high vacuum for 16 h.
elements.clean_text:
General Considerations

The X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance system equipped with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) at a scan rate of 10 s deg-1. The gas sorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 volumetric gas adsorption instrument. Typically, a sample of MOF-1 Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)⋅4DMF⋅0.5H2O (150-200 mg) was loaded and, prior to the measurements, evacuated by heating to 150 °C for 16 h until the outgas rate was <5 μm Hg/min. For MOF-2, the evacuation was carried out at 140 °C under high vacuum for 16 h.

elements.content: MOF-1 can be easily synthesized according to the published procedure in large amount with high purity. It is very stable in the mother liquid. However, it gradually becomes less transparent once it is left in the air for some time. As shown in Figure , the powder XRD of the exposed MOF-1 in the air for 3 h (Figure b) is almost identical to that of the as-synthesized one (Figure a), indicating that MOF-1 can be stable in the air for at least 3 h. When MOF-1 was exposed in the air for 16 h, some obvious changes occur in the PXRD, particularly for the one at 2θ of 10.4° from an unknown new compound (Figure c). By the comparison with that of as-synthesized one (Figure a), it was concluded that at this stage the majority of the mixture is still MOF-1. After MOF 1 was exposed in the air for 36 h, the majority of MOF-1 was transformed into MOF-2 as clearly shown in the characteristic (011) peak at the 2θ of 9.2° and (020) peak at the 2θ of 11.4° from MOF-2 (Figure d). Complete structure framework transformation from MOF-1 to MOF-2 can be fulfilled after 72 h in the air in which the (100) peak at 2θ of 8.3° from MOF-1 completely disappears as shown in Figure e.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

MOF-1 can be easily synthesized according to the published procedure in large amount with high purity. It is very stable in the mother liquid. However, it gradually becomes less transparent once it is left in the air for some time. As shown in Figure , the powder XRD of the exposed MOF-1 in the air for 3 h (Figure b) is almost identical to that of the as-synthesized one (Figure a), indicating that MOF-1 can be stable in the air for at least 3 h. When MOF-1 was exposed in the air for 16 h, some obvious changes occur in the PXRD, particularly for the one at 2θ of 10.4° from an unknown new compound (Figure c). By the comparison with that of as-synthesized one (Figure a), it was concluded that at this stage the majority of the mixture is still MOF-1. After MOF 1 was exposed in the air for 36 h, the majority of MOF-1 was transformed into MOF-2 as clearly shown in the characteristic (011) peak at the 2θ of 9.2° and (020) peak at the 2θ of 11.4° from MOF-2 (Figure d). Complete structure framework transformation from MOF-1 to MOF-2 can be fulfilled after 72 h in the air in which the (100) peak at 2θ of 8.3° from MOF-1 completely disappears as shown in Figure e.

elements.content: Time in situ powder X-ray diffraction patterns of MOF-1 (a) as-synthesized MOF-1; (b) 3 h; (c) 16 h; (d) 36 h; (e) 72 h; and of (f) the regenerated MOF-1; and (g) MOF-2 (peaks marked with * are from small amount of unknown phase).
elements.clean_text: 1  Time in situ powder X-ray diffraction patterns of MOF-1 (a) as-synthesized MOF-1; (b) 3 h; (c) 16 h; (d) 36 h; (e) 72 h; and of (f) the regenerated MOF-1; and (g) MOF-2 (peaks marked with * are from small amount of unknown phase).

elements.content: Motivated by the above-mentioned PXRD studies, we did single crystal structure determination of the exposed MOF-1 sample after 3 days. To our surprise, the exposed MOF-1 diffracts very well, and the single crystal structure determination exclusively established the nature of MOF-2 framework (Table ); thus, the framework transformation from MOF-1 to MOF-2 was clearly confirmed both by single and powder diffraction studies.
elements.clean_text: Motivated by the above-mentioned PXRD studies, we did single crystal structure determination of the exposed MOF-1 sample after 3 days. To our surprise, the exposed MOF-1 diffracts very well, and the single crystal structure determination exclusively established the nature of MOF-2 framework (Table ); thus, the framework transformation from MOF-1 to MOF-2 was clearly confirmed both by single and powder diffraction studies.

elements.content: MOF-2 is a 2D (4,4) layered framework consisting of paddle-wheel Zn2(COO)4 SBUs which are bridged by BDC linkers, while MOF-1 is a 3D α-Po framework in which the 2D (4,4) square sheets are further pillared by Dabco, so they are structurally related to each other (Figure ). The structure framework transformation from MOF-1 to MOF-2 might involve the deliberation of Dabco linkers, bonding of water molecules to the apical sites of the paddle-wheel Zn2(COO)4 SBUs, and simultaneous shifting of the 2D sheets. The reverse framework transformation from 2D (4,4) layer framework to 3D α-Po framework has been realized in an isostructural 2D MOF Cu2(BDC-F4)2(H2O)2 which can be transformed into 3D Cu2(BDC-F4)2(Dabco), and thus the possibility to transform MOF-2 back to MOF-1 was also examined. After simple addition of Dabco to MOF-2 in DMF at 110 °C for 48 h, the MOF 1 was regenerated as shown in PRXD (Figure f); thus the framework transformation between 2D MOF-2 and 3D MOF-1 are completely reversible (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: MOF-2 is a 2D (4,4) layered framework consisting of paddle-wheel Zn2(COO)4 SBUs which are bridged by BDC linkers, while MOF-1 is a 3D α-Po framework in which the 2D (4,4) square sheets are further pillared by Dabco, so they are structurally related to each other (Figure ). The structure framework transformation from MOF-1 to MOF-2 might involve the deliberation of Dabco linkers, bonding of water molecules to the apical sites of the paddle-wheel Zn2(COO)4 SBUs, and simultaneous shifting of the 2D sheets. The reverse framework transformation from 2D (4,4) layer framework to 3D α-Po framework has been realized in an isostructural 2D MOF Cu2(BDC-F4)2(H2O)2 which can be transformed into 3D Cu2(BDC-F4)2(Dabco), and thus the possibility to transform MOF-2 back to MOF-1 was also examined. After simple addition of Dabco to MOF-2 in DMF at 110 °C for 48 h, the MOF 1 was regenerated as shown in PRXD (Figure f); thus the framework transformation between 2D MOF-2 and 3D MOF-1 are completely reversible (Figure ).

elements.content: Structures of (a) MOF-1 and (b) MOF-2; and their corresponding topologies of (c) MOF-1 and (d) MOF-2 indicating their reversible framework transformation.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structures of (a) MOF-1 and (b) MOF-2; and their corresponding topologies of (c) MOF-1 and (d) MOF-2 indicating their reversible framework transformation.

elements.content: Both MOFs are well-known porous materials. The new type of porous MOF materials are particularly interesting for their application on gas separation because of their tunable and functional pore nature; we thus examined their separation capacity with respect to C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4. As shown in Figure , MOF-1 takes up a moderate amount of acetylene of 100 cm3/g at 296 K and 1 atm. Its acetylene uptake is about twice that of carbon dioxide, while carbon dioxide storage capacity is three times as that of methane; thus MOF-1 can be potentially utilized for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation. It is expectable that MOF-2 takes up a smaller amount of gas molecules because of its less porous structure; however, its selectivity for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation is significantly increased, particularly for C2H2/CO2 separation in which MOF-2 takes up 3.62 times more acetylene than carbon dioxide at 800 Torr, one of the highest separation selectivity ever reported for C2H2/CO2 separation. Interestingly, the activated MOF-2 exhibits hysteretic sorption of acetylene, which might be attributed to the flexible nature of the framework (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Both MOFs are well-known porous materials. The new type of porous MOF materials are particularly interesting for their application on gas separation because of their tunable and functional pore nature; we thus examined their separation capacity with respect to C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4. As shown in Figure , MOF-1 takes up a moderate amount of acetylene of 100 cm3/g at 296 K and 1 atm. Its acetylene uptake is about twice that of carbon dioxide, while carbon dioxide storage capacity is three times as that of methane; thus MOF-1 can be potentially utilized for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation. It is expectable that MOF-2 takes up a smaller amount of gas molecules because of its less porous structure; however, its selectivity for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation is significantly increased, particularly for C2H2/CO2 separation in which MOF-2 takes up 3.62 times more acetylene than carbon dioxide at 800 Torr, one of the highest separation selectivity ever reported for C2H2/CO2 separation. Interestingly, the activated MOF-2 exhibits hysteretic sorption of acetylene, which might be attributed to the flexible nature of the framework (Figure ).

elements.content: The gas sorption isotherms for the evacuated MOF-1 at 296 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  The gas sorption isotherms for the evacuated MOF-1 at 296 K.

elements.content: The gas sorption isotherms for evacuated MOF-2 at 296 K.
elements.clean_text: 4  The gas sorption isotherms for evacuated MOF-2 at 296 K.

elements.content: Although framework transformations have been realized in other MOFs, our work reported here is one of the very few reversible framework transformations between two porous MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, MOF-2 is also the first example of a transformed framework in the air exclusively characterized by both single and powder X-ray diffraction, highlighting the importance of suitable handling and preservation of some air-sensitive porous MOFs. Apparently water is the driving force for this framework transformation, so strict control of the moisture is certainly important to stabilize this type of air-sensitive porous MOFs. The reversible transformation between porous MOFs might initiate new synthetic methodologies for the construction of some unique porous MOFs which cannot be realized through the conventional one-pot synthesis. To synthesize the first porous MOF as the precursor followed by the framework transformation, some new porous MOFs might be realized in the near future by the implementation of two such steps approach.
elements.clean_text: Although framework transformations have been realized in other MOFs, our work reported here is one of the very few reversible framework transformations between two porous MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, MOF-2 is also the first example of a transformed framework in the air exclusively characterized by both single and powder X-ray diffraction, highlighting the importance of suitable handling and preservation of some air-sensitive porous MOFs. Apparently water is the driving force for this framework transformation, so strict control of the moisture is certainly important to stabilize this type of air-sensitive porous MOFs. The reversible transformation between porous MOFs might initiate new synthetic methodologies for the construction of some unique porous MOFs which cannot be realized through the conventional one-pot synthesis. To synthesize the first porous MOF as the precursor followed by the framework transformation, some new porous MOFs might be realized in the near future by the implementation of two such steps approach.

cln_elements.content: Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)·4DMF·0.5H2O (MOF-1) was synthesized according to the published procedure. Prism-shaped colorless crystals of MOF-2 were obtained after exposing MOF 1 in the air for more than 36 h, washed with DMF, and dried in the air. Their identities were confirmed by both X-ray single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies. These two MOF samples were used for gas adsorption studies. The regenerated MOF 1 was obtained as crystalline product by the following reaction: A mixture of MOF-2 (0.2781 g, 0.87 mmol) and DABCO (0.056 g, 0.50 mmol) was suspended in DMF (5 mL) and heated in a vial (20 mL) at 110 °C for 48 h.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Zn2(BDC)2(Dabco)⋅4DMF⋅0.5H2O (MOF-1) was synthesized according to the published procedure. Prism-shaped colorless crystals of MOF-2 were obtained after exposing MOF 1 in the air for more than 36 h, washed with DMF, and dried in the air. Their identities were confirmed by both X-ray single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies. These two MOF samples were used for gas adsorption studies. The regenerated MOF 1 was obtained as crystalline product by the following reaction: A mixture of MOF-2 (0.2781 g, 0.87 mmol) and DABCO (0.056 g, 0.50 mmol) was suspended in DMF (5 mL) and heated in a vial (20 mL) at 110 °C for 48 h.

cln_elements.content: Both MOFs are well-known porous materials. The new type of porous MOF materials are particularly interesting for their application on gas separation because of their tunable and functional pore nature; we thus examined their separation capacity with respect to C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4. As shown in Figure , MOF-1 takes up a moderate amount of acetylene of 100 cm3/g at 296 K and 1 atm. Its acetylene uptake is about twice that of carbon dioxide, while carbon dioxide storage capacity is three times as that of methane; thus MOF-1 can be potentially utilized for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation. It is expectable that MOF-2 takes up a smaller amount of gas molecules because of its less porous structure; however, its selectivity for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation is significantly increased, particularly for C2H2/CO2 separation in which MOF-2 takes up 3.62 times more acetylene than carbon dioxide at 800 Torr, one of the highest separation selectivity ever reported for C2H2/CO2 separation. Interestingly, the activated MOF-2 exhibits hysteretic sorption of acetylene, which might be attributed to the flexible nature of the framework (Figure ).
cln_elements.clean_text: Both MOFs are well-known porous materials. The new type of porous MOF materials are particularly interesting for their application on gas separation because of their tunable and functional pore nature; we thus examined their separation capacity with respect to C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4. As shown in Figure , MOF-1 takes up a moderate amount of acetylene of 100 cm3/g at 296 K and 1 atm. Its acetylene uptake is about twice that of carbon dioxide, while carbon dioxide storage capacity is three times as that of methane; thus MOF-1 can be potentially utilized for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation. It is expectable that MOF-2 takes up a smaller amount of gas molecules because of its less porous structure; however, its selectivity for C2H2/CO2 and CO2/CH4 separation is significantly increased, particularly for C2H2/CO2 separation in which MOF-2 takes up 3.62 times more acetylene than carbon dioxide at 800 Torr, one of the highest separation selectivity ever reported for C2H2/CO2 separation. Interestingly, the activated MOF-2 exhibits hysteretic sorption of acetylene, which might be attributed to the flexible nature of the framework (Figure ).

gas adsorption.condition: storage capacity is three times as that of methane
takes up 3.62 times more acetylene than carbon dioxide

| Z                  | 1                | 4 |
| ρ<sub>calc</sub> (Mg/m<sup>3</sup>) | 0.810 | 1.687 |
| μ (mm<sup>−1</sup>) | 1.050          | 1.968 |
| F(000)             | 290              | 656 |

| refinement method  | full-matrix least-squares on F<sup>2</sup> | |
| data/restraints/parameters | 661/0/37 | 2206/3/182 |
| GOF on F<sup>2</sup> | 0.957 | 0.951 |

| largest diff peak/hole [e/Å<sup>3</sup>] | 0.664/-0.358 | 0.365/-0.500 |

metadata.title: Reversible Two-Dimensional−Three Dimensional Framework Transformation within a Prototype Metal−Organic Framework
